content: Utah the USA's Online Porn Capital Utah not only led the charge with donations to pass California's constitutional same-sex marriage ban -- the state also leads the pack with the highest level of online pornography usage, as measured per 1,000 broadband subscribers. In fact, traditionally "red" states take the top three spots in a study published last week by Harvard business professor Benjamin Edelman in the Journal of Economic Perspectives. Alaska is close behind, followed by Mississippi. California is way down the list at number 39. At the time the study was conducted, the 27 states that had already constitutionally banned same-sex marriage (prior to the 2008 election) boasted 11% more porn subscribers than states that have not yet enacted or have yet to enact antigay constitutional amendments. Out of every 1,000 broadband users in the state of Utah, 5.47 are porn subscribers, according to the report. >http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid74249.asp Now that is amazing LMAO

content: Five out of a thousand huh? wow. How many of you have lived in Utah I wonder? If you had it would come as no surprise. Lotta heroin use and gang activity in West Valley City. They even have adult bookstores, but not many which would explain a higher than normal rate of online usage. Lotta non-Mormons and more rampant Mormon haters per capita than anywhere else as well. Roseanne Barr was from Salt Lake. She hates Mormons with a very vocal passion. But hey you fad mongers are too hip for me with your far reaching ability to attach porn, religion and geography in order to sneak in yet another religion bash. Hey! Feel free to chuckle at the fact that some of the nastiest *****houses and back alley whiskey rooms are located in Baghdad. And kids in the streets of the Holy city of Karbala will chase you down trying to sell you the latest porn DVDs. Not PC to bash THAT religion? Sorry. You can just tuck that info away next those pictures of you dressed like John Travolta in Urban Cowboy. You guys are so "in", so with it, so hip. I just know you were the kids who listened to Disco in highschool.

content: quote: Yeah I lived in Salt Lake, and it is so not surprising that the most religious are the biggest hypocrites, just look at Ted Haggard, Larry Craig (Idaho) and on and on. I was even married to a LDS member, who pathetically accepted at face value whatever the church said without question. How sad, the same mental weaknesses are repeated all over the world in every religion always by the most religious. You're confusing the religious with the ostentatiously "pius". Those who wear their religion as a badge of false pride and honor that sets them apart or over others. I know the type well. I also know the truly religious well. His name was Lt.Col. Jack Jones. He joined the Marines as a private during WWII. He became a Marine Raider. He rose through the ranks and obtained a commission by the time of the Korean War. He served on alot of sneaky, classifed missions around the world to include Africa. In the early stages of Vietnam, he seized a grenade that had been thrown near him and his men and threw it back. It blew off all the fingers of his left hand. When I knew him he was my Highschool social studies teacher. He was also the Bishop of the local Mormon Ward. It was the 70s. Bad economy, my dad was working two jobs and all the overtime he could get. Even my 70 year old grandfather had come out of retirement to build houses. My dad had started re-roofing our house but got stopped halfway through. Lt.Col. Jones drove by our house on his way home from work. One day he showed up on the doorstep with a hammer and tool belt. He asked my mom where the ladder was, and then he went up and finished re-roofing our house. This is the kind of thing truly religious Mormons do. I won't argue with you though. The other kind exist. As for your wife. I'm pretty sure she wanted an eternity you couldn't provide in your present state of beliefs right? This is an eternity I've pretty much given up on to stay with my wife...who you probably share a few sentiments about Mormons with. Oh well. I always figured God wasn't a bureaucrat and that he'd make things "right" no matter what the "rule book" said.
